comment._content: beautiful details

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: His waistcoat is remarkably inoffensive for the 1890s. Cover illustrations of Three Men in a Boat are usually not too far off, typically depicting Harris in an orange and yellow stripy blazer of considerable foulness.

comment._content: This picture in Panoramio may be from the same spot, looking due South at the Old Weir Bridge from this spot near Dinish Cottage.

comment.author: 41675580@N08
comment._content: What a lovely moment in time captured in this one NLI, I love it, thank you for posting.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
Have a look at this Flickr Photo below, it is remarkable that boats built in the very same way as they were in the 1880's are still used all over Irelands inland waters.

comment.author: 69751036@N08
comment._content: Those fishing rods seem to be very long.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] I cannot agree on the Dog.

The man is obviously a smartly dressed Angler and not a Fisherman!!!

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: If you look at the next in the series, the dog/hairy rock has moved down beside the mooring chain.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] I can see a dog in that one - still not convinced about the above - then of course Carol has the super dooper resolution.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: These are both titled Salmon Lake in the archive records, but I think the captions on the photos themselves say SALMON TAKE.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: I'm not by any means certain, but I think the dog is actually quite a large cat.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] Dont like Cats

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] That's as marvelously an unpunctuated a motto as "gentlemen lift the seat". Do you mean that you wish me not to like cats? Is a "dont" a collective noun of some sort and they happen to like cats? Have you left out an "I" and in fact, you don't like cats? Should we dont in the manner of a cat? The possibilities are endless!

Edit: Needs more smileys, possibly. :-)

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: The problem with smileys is once you stick one in, everyone assumes that anything without one is deadly serious.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] ?

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] Ha, it is a dog! I wasn't entirely sure, but unless there's a weird local genus of hairy moving rocks??

And I do apologise about Fisherman versus Angler. Though laughing here, as I inadvertently changed it to Fanglers for a moment...

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Excellent, another Dog, that book is nearly yours. I presume this is Take as in a place where Salmon are more willing to take a fly or a bait?

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: Like most small boats, this one is clinker-built. The shell of overlapping planks is built first. Internal timbers are then fitted. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clinker_%28boat_building%29

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] That makes sense!

And the dogs thing is happening because I relaxed. The photos with dogs were obviously able to smell my fear, and ran away...
